hello marijn.

On 2014-07-31, 0:32, marijn.huizendveld@... [rest-discuss] wrote:
> I've skimmed through rfc5988 and understood that custom link relations
> should be fully qualified URLs as well?
> So far I've applied a namespace prefix (e.g. Link: </users>;
> rel=my-namespace:users; type=application/json).
> What's are the arguments against using a namespace prefix?

it's not allowed.

> What are the arguments in favour of using a fully qualified URL?

it's allowed.

there's little point to argue about what the spec allows. it is what it 
is. we could have a chat why it has been created that way, but that's 
purely academic.

> So far it seems a bit odd to me to use a fully qualified URL because the
> link relationship value will than often coincide with the actual URL of
> the resource...

that would not be a good sign for your API. when using link relations, 
keep the following in mind:

- reuse existing link relations when possible, so that developers can 
reuse their understanding of them in the context of your API.

- link relations should not identify *what* you're linking to. that's 
one of the most common mistakes in REST design. they should identify 
*why* you might want to follow a certain link in its given context.

following these two recommendations, your link relations should change 
quite a bit, and you'll see that there is a big difference in the 
hypermedia design itself (which establishes the "context model" through 
which clients navigate), and the resources in one instance of that 
design (which are the concrete resources that a client is navigating).

cheers,

dret.
